Sudden surge or anomalous pattern in net.Action: Monitor Zeek conn.log and http.log for sudden increases in connection volume or request rates to specific internal application ports/URLs. Use time series analysis to identify statistically significant deviations from baseline traffic patterns. Analyze traffic characteristics (source IPs, user agents, request types) for correlation with known attack vectors.

High resource utilization and error logs.Data: Windows Event ID 24, Windows Event ID 25, Windows Event ID 26, Windows Event ID 1000, Windows Event ID 1001
High resource utilization and error logs.Action: Monitor Windows Event Logs (Application, System) on application/web servers for Event IDs related to application errors (e.g., 24, 25, 26), crashes (e.g., 1000, 1001), or system resource warnings occurring concurrently with anomalous traffic patterns. Correlate event timestamps with spikes detected in network logs (Zeek). Use descriptive statistics to characterize normal error rates and identify outliers.

Repeated requests to known resource-inte.Data: Zeek http.log, Windows Event Logs (Application, System)
Repeated requests to known resource-inte.Action: Analyze Zeek http.log for repeated access from potentially external source IPs to specific URLs or endpoints known to be resource-intensive. Correlate high request frequency to these endpoints with application-specific error or warning events in Windows Application/System logs (e.g., related to database connections, lengthy computations, large data processing) occurring at the same time. Use frequency analysis on requests per source IP and correlation analysis between request spikes and server error rates or resource utilization metrics.

Anomalous distribution or content within.Action: Analyze Zeek logs (http.log, conn.log) for traffic targeting application services. Use descriptive statistics (e.g., mean, median, IQR) and distribution analysis (e.g., box plots of request sizes, inter-arrival times of requests) to identify anomalous patterns in request content, size, or timing from source IPs compared to historical baselines. Look for rapid sequences of specific requests or queries that deviate from normal application usage patterns or typical protocol behavior.
